On Wed, 28 Jul 2004 08:12:55 -0700, John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
> >From: Philip Tucker <ptucker@...>
> >
> > > For example, a random input node.  Either assign it a random value at
> > > the beginning of an each activation, or have its value change every time
> > > it is read.  The network will, of course, evolve to minimize the weights
> > > to the random node.  But the presence of random fluctuations in the
> > > environment will force it to adopt a different strategy of execution.
> >
> >We tried this with our tic-tac-toe player and it didn't seem to make
> >much difference.
> 
> I wouldn't expect it to make a difference for games.  I would only expect it
> to help for a controller.

Why not?  There are plenty of game domains where generating random
behavior is beneficial.  For example, the current best poker AI uses a
probability distribution to decide among prospective moves.  In poker,
an easily recognizable (i.e. deterministic) strategy can often be
disastrous, especially if your opponent picks up on it.  In other
words, unpredictability is advantageous in many game domains.

In Tic-Tac-Toe, when a player is presented with a blank board at the
beginning of a new game, how do you decide where to play?  If a neural
network were completely deterministic, it would make exactly the same
opening move every time.  Let's say for the sake of argument that it
plays in the center.  But what if it's playing against a suboptimal
opponent that knows how to block threats involving the center space,
but not those along the edges?  If the deterministic neural network
never varied its play, it would never find this weakness.

A random input may not be the best way to evolve random behavior, but
there's little doubt that the ability of a player to generate
randomness in many game domains is an important feature.

Derek
